description: From Medieval Latin lībrāta, from Latin lībra (“pound”).

entries.meaning: (now historical) A piece of land having a value of one pound per year.

description: From the participle stem of Latin lībrāre, from lībra (“a balance”).

verbs.description: librate (third-person singular simple present librates, present participle librating, simple past and past participle librated)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To place in a balance; to weigh.
(intransitive) To oscillate (like the beam of a balance).
examples: Their parts all librate on too nice a beam.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be poised; to balance oneself.
examples: Her playful Sea-horse  […]  His watery way with waving volutes wins, / Or listening librates on unmoving fins.
